# About Me.

Hi, I am Kevin Glover, user interface designer, front-end developer, instructional designer. And I’m superserious about technology. More specifically, the technology we use to communicate with each other: front-end software. My passion is making interactions between humans and technology better by applying the principles of usability, user experience, and design.

Tinkering with layouts, source codes, and prototypes is what makes me jump out of bed every morning. It takes dedication and a lot of hard work, but being able to create the right look-and-feel is worth it. To me, design is all about getting to the heart of a problem, analyzing it completely, and surpassing expectations.

title: Just Do It
markdown:
> Nobody cares.

<cite>–Everybody at some point in time. </cite>

That is the one sentence that has kept me from doing so many things. What could I possibly say or do that hasn’t been done before better? Even now, the delete key is calling me to erase the minimal progress that I have done. There are a lot of people that influence me, and, when I think of them, everything I type seems… lessen. I mean, wouldn’t you rather read something written by Dan Wieden than by somebody influenced by him?

You may know Wieden as the co-founder of Wieden+Kennedy, the prolific advertising agency responsible for the 1988 Nike campaign that coined the phrase “Just Do It.” If you didn’t, then you do now. That slogan was meant to sell shoes, but it did o much more. It embodied the <del>American</del> human spirit and motivated people to do the things they thought impossible.

I try not to thing about things in terms of whether they are possible or not, I just see a problem I want to solve. To me, there is a solution to everything. That outlook may seem super optimistic, but this light has a deep shadow.

Whenever I start something big, something important, I put everything I have into it. It is deeply personal, and I become completely dedicated. This is a risky strategy because I get really close to my work. Obsessed. I put in overtime and put off eating to solve that one last problem. Because I am convinced there is a solution that I need to discover. There is hardship in my quest to get everything to work just right. It pays off in the end because my passion is evident in the product. But getting to the point where I feel comfortable showing off the product is difficult.

That is why writing is so hard for me. It is very certain that what I write will not be perfect. Good, passionate, thought-provoking writing is a skill that needs to be honed over time. Like exercise, it is easy to quit after months of not seeing any improvement. I can’t quit. Or I have to keep quitting quitting. Great artist were not great because they were born great, but because they worked at it over and over again.

Whew. That wasn’t so bad. I just conquered a bad guy in my game of life: the Non-Self Starter.

Just do it.

title: Scrolling along the X-axis
markdown:
After installing Windows 8, I had an realization. Horizontal scrolling made sense. Then I noticed that Win8 was not the first to implement this. Lots of apps for the iPad use horizontal scroll in landscape mode, like Google+ and Paper. And aren’t we typically using our desktops in landscape mode? By displaying content along the x-axis, you can show more content at a time! The more I thought about it, the more sense it made. Ancient scrolls even used a horizontal scroll of sorts.

![Scroll](http://www.superserio.us/assets/Scroll.jpeg)  
 Horizontal scrolling has been around since, well, scrolls where invented. It fell out of vogue first with bounding books and then when early computers came around. In both cases, the hardware at the time favored a vertical display of content.

So then I had an idea. Maybe, just maybe, I could bring this to the web. It turns out that there are lots of websites that implement horizontal scrolling. However, with the exception of Tumblr, all the sites I found were custom sites: sites created for a singular use.

Even though I had only made a handful of site using WordPress, I knew I wanted to use it. WordPress is a very cool CMS, and I wanted to learn more about the theme creation process and PHP. And wow, did I ever. There is a saying that you never know what you don’t know until you start learning about it. Basically, the whole ignorance is bliss argument.

This has really been a huge learning experience. Still have a lot of things to learn.

The most important lesson that I have learn so far is from a Smashing article I read while researching on creating WP themes: “A theme is never done.” This theme is going to get refined and change over time. Heck, a year from now I may discover that horizontal scrolling is not all it’s cracked up to be. But I am glad that I took the first steps. I created my own theme and nothing is going to change that.

title: Lorem ipsum no more.
markdown:
Lorem ipsum refers to placeholder text that is often used when designing layouts and websites. It is fascinating that this particular form of dummy text has survived to become tradition today. Some programs, like Dreamweaver, even have built-in lorem ipsum generators.

There is a logic to using lorum text in layouts. According to lipsum.com,

> It is a long established fact that a reader will be distracted by the readable content of a page when looking at its layout. The point of using Lorem Ipsum is that it has a more-or-less normal distribution of letters, as opposed to using ‘Content here, content here’, making it look like readable English.

However, this explanation for its purpose also illustrates why we should **not** be using lorem ipsum in our layouts. Simply put, lorem ipsum is bad practice because it distracts from the design and discourages legibility.

When using lorem ipsum for layouts it is harder to get useful feedback from stakeholders or even just random people walking by. These may be the best people to talk to if you want a fresh perspective or direction. But if you have to preface the conversation with “this is just Latin text that you don’t need to understand,” you are alienating your reviewers with a foreign language. You want to create an environment where people feel comfortable sharing their opinions. Explaining something like dummy text, could make the reviewer question their credentials, and anything that could make the reviewer “feel dumb” should be avoided. You lose out on valuable feedback when potential reviewers withhold their reactions to your design.

Secondly, you want to ensure that whatever content will replace the placeholder text will be easily digested. How can you test the legibility of the content if the placeholder text is not meant to be read? Lorem ipsum may *look* like readable English, but it cannot act as a measurement of readability.

So what can you do instead of using this outdated method for filler text? Get creative! Sometimes I use paragraphs from public domain books like “Alice in Wonderland” in my layouts. It looks like actual content from a distance, and you can easily test its legibility. Choosing an interning story will also encourage reviewers to actually read the sections, which allows you to evaluate the flow of the layout. If reviewers skip sections or squint a lot, you know there are some issues to deal with.

Make your placeholder text work with your design, not against it. Go ahead and ditch the ipsum. You and your reviewers will be happy that you did.

title: Vertical Bias
markdown:
> You have to know the rules, so you know which ones to break.

I was talking to my friend about web design. He wanted to get into making web pages and was looking for some tips. (I am the “designer guy” of my social circle, so I am the go-to person for these kind of things. It is very enjoyable actually; I get lots of different perspectives from them on something that I am very close to.)

My friend was tired of websites that didn’t take advantage of his wide screen monitor and wanted to make sure that his own personal site was optimized for landscape views. He wanted know if there was an easy way to make horizontally scrolling sites.

And this is where the title of this post comes from. The short answer is no, there is no easy way of making a webpage scroll horizontally.

The web as we know it today has a heavy bias towards vertical design. The way that HTML and CSS functions is based on this principle of wrapping elements between the right and left edges of the

. Fundamentally, all webpages are optimized for vertical scrolling. Like gravity, this basic principle was invisible to me until I tried to break it. To understand why vertical scroll is so fundamental, you have to understand the box model that CSS follows. The “float” attribute is the basic wrapping mechanism used for styling elements. This replaces the default behavior of just positioning elements down a single column. Floated objects are placed next to each other until they run out of room and drop down to create a row. The pattern is to create row after row after row. There is no way of changing the behavior of elements to form columns natively.

The inherit behavior of CSS is to create layout that scroll vertically. So why fight it? Because I believe that there are times when horizontal layouts are more optimal. And this is where the title of this post comes from. The short answer is no, there is no easy way of making a webpage scroll horizontally.

title: 5 Lorem Ipsum Alts
markdown:
> Neque porro quisquam est qui dolorem ipsum quia dolor sit amet, consectetur, adipisci velit…

What does this quote mean? To the average reader, it doesn’t mean anything. It is just words.

The quote is a bit of lorem ispum, dummy text commonly used as a placeholder in layouts.

While it is better than using ‘Content here, content here’ over and over again, it is not the best way of determining legibility or eliciting feedback. The reviewer can’t relate to lorum ipsum because it is just nonsense to them. You won’t get much more feedback than “this is too small, I think” or “Is this even English?” This kind of feedback is not very helpful when testing the usability of a design.

(BTW, the quote translates to: “There is no one who loves pain itself, who seeks after it and wants to have it, simply because it is pain…”)

When trying to evaluate a layout, you need to ensure that the text used can be read. That is the whole point of content. Lorum ipsum makes the evaluation process more difficult by requiring your reviewers to not read the content they are supposed to review.

How can you determine if the text is too small, or the font appropriate? What if you want people to actually read the text on your website? If these things are important to you (and they should be), then you might want to think about ditching the *dolor sit*.

Fortunately, there are plenty of alternatives to choose from. The following are my go-to favorites whenever I need to add some dummy text to my layouts.


## 1. [Free public domain books](http://www.authorama.com/)

Using text from books that have entered the public domain is probably my favorite method. You can pull entire chapters and re-purpose it as placeholder text. Not only is it literally created to be read by all types of readers, but it is also enjoyable to read. Try using [Alice in Wonderland](http://www.authorama.com/alice-in-wonderland-1.html) for you next design, and prepare to be pleasantly surprised at how much fun you have reviewing your layouts.


## 2. [Fillerati](http://www.fillerati.com/)

Like the idea of using text from classic books, but don’t want to take the time to track down the one you really want, then copy and paste the text? Well then this is the tool for you, time-conscience bibliophile!

Fillerila takes paragraphs from a list of classical novels, from Moby Dick to the War of the Worlds. You will be sure to find something that suits your needs.


## 3. [Malvole Text Generator](http://www.malevole.com/mv/misc/text/)

Don’t be fooled by the name, this text generator is also a lot of fun. It creates paragraphs of text taken from old 80′s television show themes. For instance:

*Ten years ago a crack commando unit was sent to prison by a military court for a crime they didn’t commit. These men promptly escaped from a maximum security stockade to the Los Angeles underground…*


## 4. [Not Lorem Ipsum](http://notloremipsum.com)

Not Lorem Ipsum is almost cheating as it is not so much a generator, but a collection of filler text specifically written for different industries. It is still an amazing service that gives you a lot of possibilities. You can choose filler text in categories such as startup, accounting, or even cake shops/bakeries.


## 5. [Bullsh!t Ipsum ](http://bullshitipsum.com/?paragraphs=2)

Saving the <del>best</del> most entertaining for last, Bullsh!t ipsum generates filler text that would feel at home at any office space. The paragraphs are nonsense, but they are chocked full of the best marketing jargon I have ever seen. This filler text would probably even fool upper management! (Just kidding).

Take a gander at sentences like:

*Niche e-markets e-business visualize and revolutionize front-end benchmark networking mashups, portals, e-enable aggregate front-end infrastructures?*

or

*Rich-clientAPIs; virtual: seamless wikis 24/365 sexy networking recontextualize; whiteboard podcasting matrix extensible post platforms, productize networking.*

title: Tessa: my very own VI.
markdown:
Tessa started out as a dream of mine: to create a virtual assistant that could control house, manage my activities, and communicate with me. I wanted to take the best parts of Siri and Google Now, along with the fictional systems like Jarvis and HAL, to create a VI that anybody could install. I knew this would be a difficult task, but I figured that with enough work I would be able to accomplish my goal. As my computer science friend told me, I was trying to paint the Mona Lisa right after taking Art 101. That didn’t phase me; I knew that it would be a journey. And every journey starts with a single, humble step. So I stepped right into it. I started with researching AIML, the Artificial Intelligence Markup Language first developed in the 90s. It is basically XML, so it was easy for me to understand the core building blocks. The servers were typically java, which took some refreshers, but also manageable. However, since AIML is so old, many of the projects are pretty much abandonware last updated 2001. It seemed like all the source code was written using old versions of XCode that I couldn’t open. So I turned to ChatScript, which ended up opening a whole new world to me. This chatbot script is made for server side communication; and it has greate documentation. I was able to easily set up a local Ruby server using Sinatra and connect it to my ChatScript server. All of this is local, so I can access my Terminal and Apple-script commands. Oh yeah, I learned all about that too. Apple-script is so cool. I love that I can basically do any command programmatically, even keystrokes, in any program. So from my Sinatra server, I can execute Ruby functions that can in effect execute Terminal, Apple-script, or even Python functions! Basically, my whole computer can be connected to Tessa. Python makes it very easy to get JSON data from APIs, so I use that to pull information from databases like Freebase, Weather, and Maps. I can also send data packets to services like Gmail and Google Calendar. I now have the ability for Tessa to communicate with my schedule, read emails, and tell me reminders. The biggest obstacle I have faced is the verbal communication. It is interesting that I didn’t think this was going to be a problem. Fortunately, Google Chrome has a very useful input attribute **x-webkit-speech**. This adds speech recognition to any input field! It also has a cool API, so I can control what happens once the speech is transcribed. In my case, I just want to submit the input to the Sinatra server that then handles the ChatScript exchange. As a bonus, writing a small Apple-script function allowed me to activate the Chrome speech-to-text input by verbal command. This allows me to say, “Hey, Tessa,” and the corresponding tab activates and begins listening. When I want Tessa to talk back to me, I simply pass the response to the Terminal **say** command. And voila! I can talk to Tessa and she talks back. The only downside to doing the response this way is that I cannot interrupt Tessa once she has started talking. Additionally, handling the speech using Chrome and Apple specific commands really limits Tessa to Mac-only. But the whole setup isn’t processor heavy; I have her living on my old Mac Mini. I really feel like I am standing on the shoulders of giants, but it is really fun to push the limits of my knowledge and make different technologies work together. There are still lots of commands that I need to finish before Tessa is completed, and I still need to incorporate some home automation functionality, but it is still a great project to tinker with. Will another VI come out before Tessa is ready? I’m sure of it. However, it wasn’t my goal to be first. I want to create something that works for me. Maybe one day Tessa will work for other people too. For now, I am happy using her as an excuse to be creative and continue growing my skills.

title: Proposals and Design 101
markdown:
We are surrounded by objects that were carefully planned. We live in a very intelligently designed space – from our computers to our coffee cups to the shoes on our feet. Each of these products had to be developed for a specific purpose to accomplish a specific task. I think that is pretty cool.

I find myself thinking about all the alternatives that failed to make the cut. More specifically, the proposals for the products that failed to make it to production. A proposal is an idea. It is a depiction of a future that the proposal writer wants to happen.

 [It says much about human nature that the future we want to create is one better than the present. You never see a proposal saying, "Fund this project and things will be worst!"] Due to my work and friends, I find myself listening to many proposals in the making. Unfortunately, translating an imagined product onto paper so others can understand it is a hard thing to do. Reality tends to get in the way. A proposal that neglects reality is a bad proposal. Maybe this is the economist in me, but we have to work with the reality we have.

Fortunately, the problem of making an intangible idea tangible, while working in a limited universe, has been addressed in interaction design. If applied at the beginning of the proposal writing process, interaction design principles can help focus your idea. Focus; that is the difference between the imaginary and the real. In the mind, a product is fluid; there are limitless possibilities and an object can morph to fit any scenario. In reality, a product is rigid, shaped, and purposed. Focus is so important because if you don’t have a solid idea, you can’t make a solid proposal. All you can do is dream.

title: Future of Feeling Better
markdown:
It sucks when things don’t go your way. I mean, sometimes it feels really, really bad. Confucius said, “To be wrong is nothing unless you continue to remember it.”  
 I don’t really think remembering failure is the problem most people have; it is getting past it.

But what if there was an app for that? I am not talking about the “motivational” apps that spew out a random platitude. I want something that knows how to cheer me up automatically. The dream: computers that can read minds. Well now they can.

With the [Muse headband, ](https://www.shoplocket.com/products/PaxCP-pre-order-your-muse "Muse Preorder website") I would be able to transmit my brainwaves to my iOS or Android device. So when my phone app picks up that I am sending off sad vibes, it can automatically try to cheer me up. How cool would that be?

But what would this app look like? How would the notifications popup? That’s the fun part because it is still in the realm of imagination. If I had my app hooked up to my home music system, maybe it could start playing my favorite band. Or maybe it could set the air conditioner to the perfect temperature. Or even make me a cup of coffee. I think the first step would be informing me of some good news like, “Hey, your stock just went up!” or “You just got another follower on your Blog!” Make the message positive, personal, and genuine.

title: Symphonacci
markdown:
The central idea behind Symphonacci was creating music using math formulas. It was the result of one brainstorming session I had with a colleague. The goal was to create a site that allowed for creating and sharing; to creating a user interface that made it easy to mix music tracks. title: Kevin, Parallax
markdown:
> Parallax is a displacement or difference in the apparent position of an object viewed along two different lines of sight, and is measured by the angle or semi-angle of inclination between those two lines

<cite>[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallax)</cite>

Parallax websites are pretty cool. When it first hit the scene in 2010, it was mind-blowing. However, parallax scrolling wasn’t extremely popular until a small Nike side project, nikebetterworld, got a lot of attention from web award sites. Then it exploded. There was a time when every site had a scrolling parallax background, even ones that didn’t need one. Especially sites that didn’t need it.

Since then there has been a backlash against needless parallax backgrounds. Nikebetterworld.com has changed their site completely removing the moving background that made it so prolific. It goes to show that content, not the form or programming behind it, is king. It is important to realize and understand that the words matter more than the background.

[I made a parallax site for my own portfolio page.](http://www.superserio.us/kevin) As silly as it seems now, at the time it seemed like a rite of passage of sorts. I tried to stay away from the cliché of using images to show displacement, so I only used divs and colors. While it showcases my skills, it is not the best experience for reading. Therefore, it is not as strong as it could be, which is a problem. Good design should be both aesthetically pleasing and highly functional. The best sites are aesthetically beautiful because they function so well.

title: Intelligent Design
markdown:
I was working today when I thought about something I read in the Steve Jobs biography. While discussing the workflow at Apple, Jobs consistently focused on projects. Not the products, the entire process of envisioning, designing, manufacturing, marketing. Jobs realised that user experience depended on a high attention to detail from end to end. He focused on ensuring that his products were designed very closely to their designed purpose.

I feel like this product-oriented mentality is endangered today in the software industry. I see many technology companies positioning themselves as “service-oriented” and pushing generic software to meet unique customer needs. You see were I’m going with this? Generic products; unique customers. It will never work! The products that these companies are producing aren’t best suited for their customers because they weren’t designed from end-to-end with them in mind.

While it is true that some aspects of technology can be molded to fit a variety of different needs (take WordPress for example), the main functions have to be tactically designed for maximum effectiveness.

title: Incremental Improvement using Criticism
markdown:
> Everyone’s a critic.

Working with lots of different people is a good way to experience different forms of criticism. Some people are a joy to work with and give constructive criticism that leads to a wonderful working relationship. This post is not about those kind of people. This is about working with the polar opposite, the photo negative, the person that can only say “no.”

Believe it or not, I don’t mind working with naysayers. There is a special art to it. You have to believe that they, the negative critic, wants something that you want- not to fail. It is important to remember that, even when it seems like they are doing everything in their power to put down ideas.

It all comes down to vision. 99% of the time, they have an idea of what a successful product looks like, and you are not giving it to them. It also comes down to control. Some people don’t like an idea that isn’t their own. Both of these are good! And the answer is communication.

Starting with a bunch of problems and a blank sheet of paper is hard. However, this is how most design ideas are first created. The idea is born in the mind. It is influenced by other similar products that work (at least to the one envisioning the new product). Ideas are perfect, as long as they stay inside the mind.

That is why you cannot argue against an idea; they are shifty and formless. If somebody want an idea, give it form by sketching it. Make the idea real. Once you can *see* an idea, it can be criticized. It is always interesting to see me present a concept based off the *exact* specifications be brutally cut down by the originator. This is when I get excited.

Why? Because brutal criticism is where improvements occurs. It just happens in small increments. Each time a design in torn apart, I understand a little bit more about the critic. Think of it as a mind game. Involved them in the redesign process. Make them take ownership of the concept. It is up to the designer to distill the feedback: shifting through baseless opinion and finding genuine issues. Tweaking the design to give them what they really want, and not taking credit. By going slow, you can ensure buy-in, which is important. Incremental design is like inception. You have to go much deeper into the process, but the change is for good.

title: So, I got my Pebble.
markdown:
Back in early 2012, I was researching Kickstarter to help teach a class on proposal writing. One of the first things I did as a newly-anointed crowd-sponsor was to put in for the most popular project at the time: Pebble. I was lucky enough to get in early, so I got the early-bird sponsor price, which was really cool. Little did I know that the project would go on to raise over $10 million in funding.

The expected release date was late 2012, but it got pushed back to early 2013. All through this, there was substantial hype over Pebble, cumulating in a CES appearance. Of course the media elite got early copies, so like the rest of the plebs, I finally got my Pebble in the mail today, over 6 months since I first made my donation. Was the wait worth it?

### Unpacking

I am easily excited by creative packaging, and the Pebble did not disappoint. The simple cardboard box has “it’s time” on the front in a calming font, reminiscent of the Hitchhiker’s Guide. On the back, a standard product requirement spec, but nicely done.

[![meet-pebble-ks](http://www.thecontentist.com/wp-content/media/meet-pebble-ks.jpg)](http://www.thecontentist.com/wp-content/media/meet-pebble-ks.jpg)

When I opened the box, admittedly, I was a little underwhelmed. The only thing in the box was the Pebble itself and its charging cable. Instructions to go to go.getpebble.com were printed on the top flap. No booket or paper certificate? Oh well, this is the digital age after all.

[![inner-packaging-ks](http://www.thecontentist.com/wp-content/media/inner-packaging-ks.jpg)](http://www.thecontentist.com/wp-content/media/inner-packaging-ks.jpg)

### Setting up

The Pebble support page made me sad; it looked like a github page with the standard black header and a column of instructions. It’s a shame; the support page is a direct link to existing customers. Providing excellent support ensures your customers stay happy and builds trust.

This was the first experience I had with my new Pebble, and it already felt like a let down. For contrast, when I set up my Nest, it felt like an experience. The setup page was beautiful because it didn’t just tell me how to set up my thermostat, but it set a mood. It was delightful, and made me feel special for buying a Nest. There were videos and support was easy to find and understand.

I felt like I stumbled through the Pebble setup process. I didn’t know what to do when I first turned on the device, and there weren’t any clear guides. My Pebble froze because it was trying to update, and I couldn’t figure out how to reset it manually.

Through a Google search (and trial-and-error), I was able to figure it out that I had to hold down the select button (which wasn’t labeled). My morale was pretty low, but I had this shinny new toy and, by George, I was going to play with it!

[![pebble-v-nest-support](http://www.thecontentist.com/wp-content/media/pebble-v-nest-support1.png)](http://www.thecontentist.com/wp-content/media/pebble-v-nest-support1.png)  
 Support Pages: [Pebble ](http://help.getpebble.com/customer/portal/articles/955557-getting-started---ios "Pebble Support")(left) and [Nest](http://support.nest.com/ "Nest Support"). The Pebble page wasn’t what I expected at a launch. It’s not as user-friendly, or as helpful, as the Nest.

### The App

After I installed the app on my iPhone, connecting was a breeze. The Pebble app was a bit odd though, and it took me a bit to comprehend how the navigation worked. It uses a swipe-style of navigation that, while would have felt right on a Windows phone, was off-putting on my device. I was looking for a menu and ended up relaunching the app just to get back to the home screen. The only reason I discovered the navigation was by attempting to scroll down the page. Like I said, it felt odd.

[![ks-app-home](http://www.thecontentist.com/wp-content/media/ks-app-home.png)](http://www.thecontentist.com/wp-content/media/ks-app-home.png)  
 The Pebble app didn’t have any visual cues telling me to swipe to navigate.

### Conclusion

While getting my Pebble setup was a big-pain, I am more confident with using the product. It looks slick, and it is easy to install the handful of apps on it. title: Don't Stop Button
markdown:
I never really thought about the lack of a “stop” button before. The whole concept of stopping music seems a bit archaic – hearkening back to cassette players that would actually stop mechanically. With mp3 players, the only stopping is turning off the power, and how many times do you turn off your iPhone? With an always-on device, there is no stopping – only pauses between listening sessions.

Maybe the disappearance of the stop button is indicative of our current high-speed culture. A usability feature born from a changing mindset of needs and desires. I don’t want to stop. Don’t stop thinking or moving, or going forward. Go. Go. Go. How can we not push forward with all our speed and conscious? The reason there is not an off switch on the iPod was because Jobs didn’t want to think about life as something that could be ended with a flick of the finger. Maybe that’s why we also don’t have stop buttons. We see our own mortality in the technology we create and use.

title: MERC Website
markdown:
The website for Mercer Engineering Research Center came about when me and my comrade were approached to redesign several marketing items for our company. Designing the website was a pretty exciting opportunity; this would be the online face of MERC, so it was a big deal to me. I was responsible for coming up with the information architecture, layout, and eventual coding of the site. It also meant that I had to meet and review with managers and executives on a regular basis. The original idea was to use the same architecture as the current site at the time in order to reuse as much content as possible. However, that wasn’t to be. Being able to back up design decisions with solid proof is essential. It takes the opinions out of the argument and allows for honest, constructive conversations. The final product we created was a product of all the feedback, research, and personal passion. And I think that it is better for all the meetings and various inputs.

title: The Prince and EntreLeadership
markdown:
Whenever new information is presented, it is analyzed against existing knowledge to form a new synthesis of understanding. This is the process of learning. Since I finished Dave Ramsey’s EntreLeadership, I have been processing the themes introduced. The general philosophies seem so simple and straightforward that it borders on brashness. Which is not a bad thing. I feel the harsh truth is more valuable than a harsh lie.

The one thing that I can’t shake is how close the philosophies are to Niccolo Machiavelli’s The Prince, yet how different they are. EntreLeadership plays an interesting game of aligning very closely with The Prince, but then veering far off-course in one direction, only to come back and veer off in the other.

One example where the two text run in unison is where they discuss goal planning and communication.

A secret man does not communicate his designs to anyone or take any advice, but as on putting them into effect they begin to be known and discovered. They being to be opposed by those he has about him, and this is easily diverted from his purpose.

A prince ought always to take console, but only when he wishes, not when other wish. He ought to be a great asker, and a great hearer of the truth about those things which he has inquired.

An EntreLeader is honest, unnerving, calculating, and motivated in order to get the most out of their employees. Take away honesty and you have the recipe for a prince. This is where the main difference lies. The princes in Machiavelli’s book used dishonesty as a tool to stay in power and manipulate their citizens. It is important to remember that princes lived in a time when they could be overthrown and their families murdered.

In today’s culture, Ramsey does not have to worry about his employees staging a bloody revolution, but I wonder, if revolution was a possibile, would have different views about disclosure. Based on his description of his hiring and firing process, I can’t believe that some ex-employees don’t hold grudges. Both Ramsey and Machiavelli warn leaders against entrusting in their fortresses (business) and not tending the favor of their citizens (employees).

The infamous “ends justifies the means” line is reiterated in EntreLeadership as the reason behind the punishments and rewards introduced. These are things that have to happen for the *preservation* of the business.

A man who wishes to make a profession of goodness in everything, must necessarily come to grief among so many who are not good. Therefore, it is necessary for a prince, who wishes to maintain himself, to learn how not to be good. Everybody sees what you appear to be, few feel what you are, and those few will not dare to oppose themselves to the many.

One of the chief maxims from The Prince is that it is not necessary for a prince to **have** faith, charity, and religion, but it **is** necessary to **seem** to have them.

Ultimately, we don’t know how Dave Ramsey is in his personal life. We can’t *know * anybody’s inner thoughts. And there is no way of knowing what is in the mind of an EntreLeader. We only know what we are presented and what we interpret. The big employee events, the executive retreats, and the book are all symbols as well as activities to further goals.

The fact that books written so long ago still hold relevance today is so interesting to me. I feel like we should continue to explore the current trends, but still appreciate the classics. If you don’t understand the philosophies behind the methods, then you are only seeing part of the whole.

title: How to set up Natural Scrolling
markdown:
If you have ever used a smart phone, you have used what is called “Natural Scrolling.” It is also known as the reverse scrolling that is default on iOS computers, where scrolling up on the scroll wheel moves the screen up and scrolling down on the scroll wheel scrolls down.

To those accustomed to touch screens and Macs, this scroll behavior may seem obvious, but it’s not the default way to scroll on Windows PCs.

I was stumped on how to emulate this scrolling behavior on my Windows machine- I didn’t have specific mouse software to change the direction the scroll wheel moves the page.

Fortunately, Indiana University IT was able to provide a succinct answer to this problem: edit the mouse registry to inverse the scroll direction.

There is a little known property in the mouse registry aptly named FlipFlopWheel. The default is set to 0; changing that value to 1 will inverse the scroll wheel direction!

First, navigate to the registry editor by typing regedit in the start menu.

Next, open the folder path **HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE/SYSTEM/CurrentControlSet/Enum/HID/VID_###/###/DeviceParameters**

The ### are random numbers that are hexadecimal strings representing specific hardware or hardware locations. For me, the mouse hardware was the first VID_### number in the HID folder.

Then find the FlipFlopWheel property in DeviceParameters. Double click it and change the value to 1. A reset is necessary for the register to adjust, and, once you do, you will be really to go. The UI IT instructions are written for Windows 7, but I did it on a Windows 8 machine and it worked awesomely.

[You can find the full instructions on the IU IT page here.](http://ittrainingtips.iu.edu/windows-7/windows-7-how-to-invert-your-mouses-scroll-wheel/02/2012 "How to Invert Your Mouse’s Scroll Wheel")

title: Coming to a Disagreement
markdown:
Actually disagreeing with somebody isn’t easy. Pointing at somebody and calling their opinion stupid is easy. Being stubborn is easy. But disagreement takes effort. When you disagree with somebody, you are saying that you understand their thought process and their logic to a point, but the last step is not correct. You would come to a different conclusion based on the same information. In order to do that you have to have a relationship with the person you are disagreeing with. You have to empathize with their situation and see things from their point of view. And that’s not easy to do. However, it is something that needs to happen in order for harmony and compromise.

Disagreement has lots of implementations, and I keep it in mind whenever I am brainstorming, designing, or even chatting with friends. Disagreement comes up a lot in user-centered-design. Because of the time, effort, and, frankly, tension of disagreement, I feel like people see this as a negative aspect of UCD. But, as you may have guessed, I think that disagreements are awesome.

User-centered design is all about building relationships with the users. Not every user is going to agree with your design, layout, or execution. You have to understand why they think and act the way they do. If you just make the changes they explicitly say, you are not building an understanding; you are not building a relationship, you are not being empathetic, and you are not creating harmony or compromise. You are force feeding them their own words. To being out truly delightful designs, you have to come to a disagreement.

The most important part of disagreements, it getting past them. If you take the time to have built a good enough relationship to reach an disagreement, then you also have the tools to resolve it. Empathy and trust are the keys to compromise. As social beings, we are hardwired to compromise and find solutions. As much as we tend to argue and find points of contention, we also enjoy finding creative ways to revolve our differences. In the end, we are solutions looking for problems.

title: Can I be an hedgehog?
markdown:
After reading Good to Great by Jim Collins, I was struck by the notion that successful businesses are successful because they identify a singular area where they can be the best in the world and pursue that are rigorously. When Collins and his team lay out the evidence from their study, the conclusion seemed very substantial. Successful businesses develop around a pursuit of being the best at one thing; they are as Collins called it a hedgehog. Unlike foxes that are cunning and try to survive with diversity, hedgehogs strive by specializing in one thing: defense. And they beat foxes with this strategy.

I feel like every individual is like a separate company. Each individual has a input, output, cost, income, and profit margins that need to be considered. However, can an individual be a hedgehog? Or more importantly, would it be a good idea for a person to be a hedgehog? The definition of a hedgehog strategy is that you find what you think you can be the best in the world at and you focus on growing that core capability. Collins mentioned his wife winning the Iron Man as an example. So people can adopt hedgehog principles for their life. But would you want to?

The fact that you have to define yourself isn’t what I find unappealing about a personal take on the hedgehog strategy, it is the limitation. Over specialization can be a disadvantage in a changing environment, like say technology or web design. But on the other hand, focusing on a technology can be part of a hedgehog strategy.

Looking at hedgehogs makes me think that we are on the cusp of a new ideology about the ideal self. It was that renaissance men (and women) where what people strived to become. DeVinci, Jefferson, de Medici, and Tesla, these were the examples placed before me. These people were not hedgehogs. They were not foxes. The only animal that could describe their action would be human.

Why should we place limits on ourself? It may be harder to accomplish, but wouldn’t it be better to strive for excellence all around than to build up on aspect and ignore the others? Maybe it is too much, and we live in a “new economy.” Not one that discourages the principles that are in Good to Great, but an age defined by them.

What is there not to enjoy about a sans-serif font? Well, the legibility for one. Fortunately, Lato has a unique hybrid quality to it. Don’t get me wrong, it is definitely very modernist, but there is a humanistic flare to the way the letters slope and curve.

In practice, I’ve found that most clients prefer the versatility of Lato in it’s Hairline and Light font weights. Plus, the ability to use it as a web-font makes it more accessible than Helvetica.

title: As the Listener
markdown:
The contentist is first a listener. Too often we forget this first step. We believe that knowledge and experience can distill the world around us. That our mind is an island and that it is up to us to figure out how to shape the world around it. We are wrong. The mind is not an island, and the world around us shapes us more than we it. We are water flowing along side other water. When put in a cup, we form to the cup much like our culture and environment shape our knowledge and experience. When we listen, we are allowing ourselves to be placed in a cup of another person’s forming. We can experience things that we have not experienced, and we see more of the world in which we exist.

When it comes to design, listening not only tells me more about the people which will use the products I create, but it tells me more about myself. What am I hoping to create? Why do I care? The stories of others shape my inner self and prepare me for the process of designing for a purpose instead of designing without a goal. Design without purpose is irresponsible, and designing without listening is impossible.

# Hello. I’m Kevin Glover. Designer / Developer
### I am a compulsive designer. I believe that design is universal; if you understand the principals of design, you can design anything. I’ve designed and built websites, but also cameras, tables, and even automatic electric brew kettles.
## My Design Philosophy
My philosophy is influenced by Massimo Vignelli who stated that “Design is One.” Regardless of the medium, design should be meaningful and purposeful.With everything I do, I try to incorporate the teachings of the great designers that came before me. That’s important to innovation: standing on the shoulders of giants. For me and my designs, it’s about how to solve problems, but also in a way that is better than any other solutions that have been tried before. It’s about exploration and discovery. Trying something new, but still keeping in mind past successes.
Keeping with iterative design is essential for my design process because of its emphasis on communication. At the core of design, it’s all about communication and how we can transfer thoughts and ideas from one person to another. Allowing for a constant feedback loop helps make those lines of communication clearer, even though it is difficult for me to release incomplete work, or work that can be improved. In the end, everything can be improved.
Which leads to quality. Like many other artisans before me, I believe that quality is not something that can be compromised. Quality is not a sliding scale; it is either there or it is not. In any form of design, be it graphic, web, or otherwise, quality is the mark of craftsmanship. When You think of Design as One, as I do, quality is everything.

Really, I am just trying to have a bunch of fun making things I love. I love the digital medium and way we can use technology to share thoughts and ideas. There is so much to learn, and there is always more to discover. For me, I am never satisfied with ‘good enough,’ which causes me to delve a lot further than is necessary at times. I can’t not ask “why?” My curiosity has gotten me into trouble at times, but, then again, it has also provided me with a lot of opportunities to view new perspectives.
Currently, I am delving more into the computational side of design. Picking up more Python and obtaining a deeper understanding of the mathematics that govern the digital spaces. That’s the fun thing about the Design is One philosophy – nothing is off-limits.

title: What is Storytelling
markdown: I would say that storytelling is a way humans communicate messages, but I believe that is incomplete; storytelling caters to our primal desire for comprehension. It is a way to sustain ourselves mentally and better understand the world around us. “Odysseus is sad” is not a story. It doesn’t tell me enough. I want more. Answering the why question provides storytelling because it helps satisfy our curiosity: “Why is Odysseus sad and what is he doing about it?” When a story concludes we have closure because we feel as though we “get it” and are ready to move on to the next mystery.

title: Bootstrap: as a new standard?
markdown: If you are in web design, you have undoubtedly come across Bootstrap, the front-end framework born from designers at Twitter and now developed by the open-source community. Since its release into the world, it has become the most popular framework on the web, which begs the question: has Bootstrap’s effect on web design been detrimental? But, “Bootstrap is a crutch!” Yes, I have heard this sentiment echoed often, and, (surprise!) most of the time, I agree. For every Bootstrap site that is beautiful, there are plenty examples where the design process started and stopped with a copy+paste of Bootstrap CSS. My friend and colleague, [Jonathan Stegall](http://jonathanstegall.com/about/), recently wrote an article criticizing Bootstrap for creating “standards that designers can use in an infinite number of ways” [[link]](http://jonathanstegall.com/2014/02/24/more-on-my-bootstrap-as-new-dreamweaver-hypothesis/) In his article, he identifies how Bootstrap has too much design and creates definitions. The fact that people can simply import Bootstrap themes makes it too easy to create a poorly designed site – Good design requires thought and understanding. Design at it’s core is problem solving. So, let’s think about Bootstrap this way for a minute: > What problem does Bootstrap solve? Web design is becoming increasingly demanding visually with a greater emphasis on appearances and designing experiences. These new challenges require us as web designers to work with larger team to create a complete experience online. The days of a single web designer working and producing alone are in twilight. We are becoming incorporated with back-end developers, software engineers, and other designers. And we need a way to communicate with each other to an extent as we never had before. While there is not a need for Bootstrap to include predefined visual styles; let the designer define the border-radii and box-shadows. However, there is a need for a standard way of communicating markup and purpose in CSS. This is where I see Bootstraps’s strength: > We can use Bootstrap to create a common front-end language. HTML5 standards are vague at best (let’s not go into the minutiae of the proper use of HTML elements), so we rely on classes to create visual styles. However, this brings up the issue of how to name classes? Looking back at my own experience, I have named h1 elements in a header as either .page-title and .page-header apparently based solely on my mood at the time. Not good practice, but it happens. When *we* write the code *we* write the rules as *we* see fit. Frameworks exist to reduce inconsistency and create structure. Ultimately, it creates better communication. I know that if I use Bootstrap as a base, then my team members can come back in a understand the CSS and markup I created. I know that `.container` is a the wrapper div. I know the purpose of `col-xs-12 col-sm-6 col-md-4`. Bulky? Yes, but it makes working with other designers and developers much easier. That’s what a framework, a standard, or a language, is for. Perhaps it’s because web design has been such an isolated task for so long that we have this communication problem in the first place. CSS has rather loose naming conventions. However, Bootstrap is the most popular framework for a reason – it works. I am not talking about the visual aesthetics here: > The markup standards in Bootstrap 3 are pretty nice. Especially, when compared to some home-grown solutions. (MailChimp has a class markup that’s ok, but `lastUnit size1of2` is still a little odd – multiple lastUnit’s and lastGroup’s in a section can get confusing.) The best part of Bootstrap is if you don’t like something as it is, you can contribute and change it! This is the essence of collaboration. If we think about Bootstrap not as a style template, but as a language template, we can use we can use it as a starting point for our designs. We can use Bootstrap as a starting point for web apps. We can even use Bootstrap as a base for our Pattern Libraries. So let’s stop thinking about Bootstrap as a design framework and start using it as a starting point in our designs.

title: Times New Roman is Beautiful
markdown:
It seems like Times New Roman gets a raw deal. Originally developed in 1931, Times was revised in 1933 for increased legibility and economy of space and became Times New Roman. For over 40 years, Times New Roman was the typeface for The Times. Even when they changed fonts in 1972, the new fonts were a variation of Times New Roman. ### So why all the hate? It could be the proliferation of Times New Roman in early Microsoft products like Word. It could be the fact that it is a serif font, which is a shame. Serif fonts have their purpose, but it seems like sans-serifs are becoming prefered based on the style type alone. I mean, look at my own site! I love the way that a thin sans looks, but I also see why TNR has been so overused. Times New Roman has some really cool curves with it’s e’s and c’s that you really don’t see in serif fonts. I feel that Times New Roman is timeless. There’s a serenity to the font. And some things just shouldn’t be messed with too much. Some prefer Georgia or Garamond, but I like to stick with good ol’ Times; there is a lot of character in this classic font – plus it’s easier to pronounce.

title: Semantic HTML is about design
markdown:
Semantic html has been tossed around a lot lately and it has become a bit of a buzz word. However, I think designers/developers may be focusing on the wrong version of semantics. I believe that we are using a very literal definition.

> Semantic HTML is the use of HTML markup to reinforce the semantics, or meaning, of the information in webpages rather than merely to define its presentation or look.
> 
> [-Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_HTML)

This definition is consistent with a traditional view of the web as a place to share research documents. However, the web has evolved. Webpages are no longer a single column simulation of print nor a fixed width and presentation. The web today is filled with interactive, responsive, flowing pages and applications that stretch the definition of a “website” to its breaking point. I feel like it is time to look at a different definition of semantics.

According to the Vignelli Canon, semantics is “the search of the meaning of whatever we have to design.” It reintroduces the human-to-human element to the equation, while capturing the essence of the problem identified by the more technical definition.

> Semantics, in design, means to understand the subject in all its aspects; to relate the subject to the sender and the receiver in such a way that it makes sense to both. It means to design something that has a meaning, that is not arbitrary, that has a reason for being, something in which every detail carries the meaning or has a precise purpose aimed at a precise target.
> 
> -Massimo Vignelli

When we think about semantics in either print or web design, we shouldn’t be limiting ourselves to a form of markup because it’s not really the point of a modern web. Semantic markup in the W3C sense is only a framework for developing structured content. The conversation shouldn’t be about a *semantic* web, but a *meaningful*, or content-first, web. Markup doesn’t matter! Interactions matter!

This was a revelation to me, as I start thinking about developing more purposeful code. It probably would be best if we stopped worrying about the proper position of html tags and start focusing more on what’s inside them.

title: First Adventures in EmberJS
markdown:
I recently attended the Great Wide Open Conference in Atlanta, which exposed me to a bunch of amazing things and piqued my curiosity – the first thing that I wanted to dig my teeth into was EmberJS.

EmberJS is a JavaScript platform for webapp creation. It eliminates the boilerplate for getting data from ajax and allows you to directly display it on the page. It also has some pretty cool methods for achieving a MVC architecture in the browser.

EmberJS is very similar to AngularJS in its fundamentals, and it also uses a Handlebar templating schema. But, what made EmberJS different for me was its documentations, stability, and community.

The documentation for AngularJS is not great because the iterative development process for Angular is too rapid for them to update their docs and examples. I have run into issues where an example in their docs did not run because the version of off.

With EmberJS, their development seem much more stable and their documentation is current and friendly. There also seems to be more of a community developing around EmberJS. On GitHub, there are dozens of well written extensions for Ember, which I cannot wait to dig into.


## My First Aha

Whenever I am learning a new language, framework, or anything my payoff comes in those Aha moments when everything just clicks. That flash of understanding is the high that makes life great. Here’s something cool I realized the first day of EmberJS.

### Nesting templates

Ember can nest templates out of the box. You use {{outlet}} to capture the content of a called template, so you can have a {{outlet}} in the parent template and in the children templates. That way, the children are displayed within the {{outlet}} of the parent. That’s pretty cool!

title: To Wireframe, or to not wireframe
markdown:
Wireframes have been a staple of web design for the last decade. An artifact from print design, wireframes and mockups are as omnipresent as ever, but is that a good thing? I firmly believed high-fidelity mockups were the most important part of the design process – that they represent the visual manifestation of ideas. I believed these wireframes and mockups represented a type of currency to be traded for approval and then money. Mockups became a contract of sorts, a promise of an end goal. However, I now think differently. Through my Agile training, I’ve discovered the real only promise that can be made is that things will change. A static image is a work of fiction in an environment of fluid designs, media queries, and a diversity of devices.

At An Event Apart this year, I had the extreme pleasure of attending a talk by Andrew Clarke, who said,

> These static visuals are “bringing a knife to a gun ﬁght.” They can only communicate something that’s superﬁcial, artiﬁcial. They’re high-fructose, extra sweet, but even though they’re of little nutritional value, people love them and so they want more and more.

I don’t want to sound as if I disapprove of wireframing at all; there is a value. The purpose of wireframes should be to create a rudimentary starting point. Mockups should be developed with the idea they will be obsolete as soon as they are presented.

Web design is more than creating grey boxes and filling in colors. As much as I despise this term, making a site “look pretty” is a remarkable skill. It’s not something embarrassing at all! When I hear that term I feel like people are trivializing my knowledge, but that’s not it; “pretty” is an acceptable term. It’s packed full of meaning, and don’t we all want to make pretty (aka beautiful) designs anyways?

Sometimes, we get too focused on the details and miss out on the larger purpose. I mean, what is the point of design if not to facilitate expressiveness? As much as I love systems and tools and rules, I love flexibility and change more. That’s why I love design.
